titlestmt.titleproper: Grace Noll Crowell papers, Inclusive: 1904-1958, undated, Bulk: 1921-1955, undated

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: The Grace Noll Crowell papers contain scrapbooks, correspondence, photographs, and a movie advertisement printing plate, the majority being related to her family and her career as a poet.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Grace Noll Crowell was born in Inland, Iowa, on 1877 October 31 and graduated in 1901 with her Bachelor of Arts from German-English College in Wilton, Iowa. She married Norman H. Crowell on 1901 September 4 and had three sons, Dean, Reid, and Norton. Crowell’s family moved to Wichita Falls, Texas, in 1917, and to Dallas in 1919.

Crowell began writing poetry while immobile after giving birth to her first child. Her first written poem was “The Marshland,” and she published her first poetry book in October 1925, White Fire, winning first prize from the Texas Poetry Society. Many of her poems were published in magazines and newspapers, clippings of which appear in this collection. They illustrate various parts of life, especially homemaking, motherhood, family, holidays, and religious themes.

Crowell won numerous awards and honors for her poetry, including being named Poet Laureate of Texas in 1935, winning the Golden Scroll Medal of Honor in 1938 as National Honor Poet, and being chosen as honorary chancellor of the National Federation of State Poetry Societies in 1965. She was also chosen as American Mother of the Year by the Golden Rule Foundation in 1938. Baylor University awarded her an honorary doctorate in 1940.

Crowell had a full career of writing and publishing poetry, prose, and stories, amounting to over thirty-five published books. The most well-known books of poetry are White Fire (1925) Silver in the Sun (1928), Miss Humpety Comes to Tea (1929), Flame in the Wind (1930), Songs for Courage (1935), Light of the Years (1936), This Golden Summit (1937), and Songs of Hope (1938). Grace N. Crowell died in Dallas on 31 March 1969 and is buried at Hillcrest Mausoleum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Grace Noll Crowell papers begin in 1904 and end in 1958. The largest series is made up of scrapbooks, mainly containing Crowell’s poems, other poems, and newspaper and magazine clippings of stories on Crowell. The second largest series contains photographs of her family and colleagues at the German English College. The collection also contains correspondence, including a manuscript of “The Glowing Word,” legal documents, invitations and booklets, a Storm Lake, Iowa, newspaper with a poem by Crowell’s husband, and a separate series for a movie advertisement printing plate.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Grace Noll Crowell papers did not have any discernible organization prior to this finding aid, apart from scrapbooks and photographs being grouped together. There were several different existing inventories. Folder titles were changed and the collection was organized into series based on type of material. Scrapbooks were dismantled and placed in folders in order to preserve the pages.
The Grace Noll Crowell papers are presently arranged in four series: I. Scrapbooks, II. Personal Papers, III. Photographs, and IV. Metal Printing Plate.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Grace Noll Crowell papers, Accession #3359, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Amanda Mylin. Released on 2014-06-06.
Archivist''s Notes: These books are authored by Grace Noll Crowell and located within BearCat.
Crowell, Grace Noll. Between Eternities. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1944.
Crowell, Grace Noll. Bright Destiny: A Book of Texas Verse. Dallas: Turner Company, 1936.
Crowell, Grace Noll. Flame in the Wind. Dallas: The Southwest Press, 1930.
Crowell, Grace Noll. Journey Into Dawn. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1955.

Crowell, Grace Noll. Light of the Years. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1937.
Crowell, Grace Noll. Miss Humpety Comes to Tea and Other Poems. Dallas: The Southwest Press, 1929.
Crowell, Grace Noll. Poems of Inspiration and Courage: The Best Verse of Grace Noll Crowell. New York: Harper & Row, 1965.
Crowell, Grace Noll. The Radiant Quest. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1940.
Crowell, Grace Noll. Silver in the Sun. Dallas: Turner Company, 1934.
Crowell, Grace Noll. Songs for Courage. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1938.
Crowell, Grace Noll. Some Greater Dawn. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1943.
Crowell, Grace Noll. Songs of Faith. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1939.
Crowell, Grace Noll. Songs of Hope. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1938.
Crowell, Grace Noll. Splendor Ahead. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1940.
Crowell, Grace Noll. This Golden Summit. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1937.
Crowell, Grace Noll. The Wind-Swept Harp. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1946.
Crowell, Grace Noll. White Fire. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1934.
